A system-wide move to sustainable land management and nature-based solutions is critical to securing a climate-safe future, while also contributing to other societal goals, such as halting nature loss and delivering food security. - Stephen Cornelius, WWF
We must see a rapid shift in how we manage our land, alongside the necessary deep cuts to fossil fuel emissions, if we are to meet the 1.5¬∞C goal of the Paris Agreement. - Stephen Cornelius, WWF

... Unfortunately, our current agriculture, forestry, and other land uses are part of the problem as they contribute between a fifth and a quarter of global greenhouse gas emissions. - Stephen Cornelius, WWF
Land is both a source & a sink of carbon emissions. Good land-use choices are central to tackling the climate crisis. - Stephen Cornelius, WWF

Land use & natural climate solutions need to be taken much more seriously because both rapid decarbonisation & nature-based land-use solutions will be needed to limit warming to 1.5C. Our forests are our future. Without them we face the prospect of runaway climate change.

Countries must urgently reduce emissions from land, especially from deforestation, and increase the uptake of carbon by restoring forests through lower logging rates and natural regeneration other carbon-rich ecosystems. - Dr. Christoph Thies, Greenpeace
‚ÄúThis report comes at a critical juncture for our society & must be met with rapid government & business action to protect our forests & climate from destruction." - Dr. Christoph Thies, Greenpeace

These are warning signals that we ignore at our peril: agriculture ultimately is one of the most threatened economic sectors & most fundamental for healthy functioning of societies & communities. This report makes clear the seriousness of this threat. - Prof. Doreen Stabinsky

CC poses enormous threats to our ability to feed ourselves. The poorest and most vulnerable are on the frontlines of climate impacts on food production, & many across the world are migrating from their homes in order to be able to feed their families ...

Halting loss of carbon- & nature-rich ecosystems, empowering indigenous communities to manage land & transforming our agric. & food systems, addresses the climate crisis, enhance food security, health, and give all life on earth the chance to thrive - Beatriz Luraschi RSPB

On finance- We can't just speak about ambition if there is no support. We are one year away from the US$100 billion commitment. @Eddypc

The 1.5SR changed the way we talk about science and ambition. Countries at #SB50Bonn have mentioned how they are using the report to update their national plans. But there are key blockers, countries trying to change the way we speak about science. We need to have science here.

It is a sad moment for us (Brazil). There was a lot of momentum, we tackled deforestation and created the Amazon fund. Now that is under threat. The Brazilian NGOs and the international community can work to protect it. Support from the @Pontifex could be important. @FernandaVdeC

It's not good to prejudge an outcome on Article 6 - we came here with two texts and leave with two text and more questions. What is important right now is to know what we don't want, and that is a new CDM. The #COP25 presidency needs to allow space for discussion. @Eddypc
The impacts are escalating, the civil society movement is escalating, but what is not escalating is political will. For a year of ambition, we need governments to step up. @FernandaVdeC

We need leadership from the #G7 and the #EU. We want the EU to call another meeting, they can do that. We have the #UN Secretary-General's Summit that needs to deliver on ambition and we have #COP25 that needs to provide enhanced NDCs

We did not get strong signals here, but lots of other opportunities this year to show ambition. The GCF meeting next week is key, we need to see a doubling of the replentishments. We are hearing the #G20 might not be that ambition, but some members looking to strenghten it.
The least developed countries are fighting to ensure that their needs are recognized in loss and damage, and not dealt with just by adaptation finance or development money. @sadiedecoste

When we are talking about loss and damage, we are talking about the impacts being seen on the ground. We are talking about droughts and floods. These events are happening now and will continue to intensify. Developed countries aren't interested in meaningfully addressing this.

During this session, parties were negotiating terms of reference for the Warsaw International Mechanism for Loss and Damage. Regardless of whether the ToR are approved, the review can still take place at #COP25.

Why are we still trying to agree on the relevance of science in this space? We have seen an effort to reduce science's role here. Science has been here since the beginning & is important. This is not happening in a silo, G20 & EU recent decisions are disappointing @Eddypc

We are in a moment where we have to think about implementation and ambition. We expected countries to send strong signals on high ambition. That has not been the case. The signals are not in sync with the climate impacts being felt by the most vulnerable.

We need a deadline on when we will have a decision, can not let it go until 2022 or 2023. Some countries are already beginning to plan their NDCs in 2020. We need a decision before then. @JeffreyGQi

Not a lot of progress on Common Time Frames. Decided that it would be applied to NDC and starting in 2031. Our view is that we need to have a single common 5-year time frame. There is a general consensus between parties that the NDCs will be communicated in 2025.  @JeffreyGQi
We should have the terms of reference for Wednesday. Not yet sure what the process will be between #SB50Bonn and #COP25. Would be useful if there was a process in place. - Leia Achampong

@TasneemEssop @Davidxvx "Unleashing the power of people in unity and respect is not just possible but necessary. Now is the time to get it right."

@TasneemEssop @Davidxvx "Let us acknowledge the complexity of the task ahead and get prepared. We need to become better allies, build stronger networks and sustain each other through periods fraught with inevitable setbacks."

@TasneemEssop @Davidxvx "In this ‚Äòdecade of action‚Äô, we need climate activism that straddles other struggles like workers‚Äô rights, the rights of indigenous peoples and the fight against inequality, while demanding tax reforms and social justice."
@TasneemEssop @Davidxvx "International solidarity means ceding space and power to historically marginalised voices and shifting the spotlight to those on the frontlines."

@TasneemEssop @Davidxvx "This change means ensuring more and more people show up and feel welcomed to join the struggle for climate justice, in whatever capacity they can exercise their rights and influence."

@TasneemEssop @Davidxvx "If 2019 comes to be remembered as the year that the climate emergency finally broke through mass consciousness, 2020 must be the year we stop shifting the goalposts to accommodate weak leaders and mobilise the power of people to tip the scales towards lasting change."

To start the conversation in 2028 on whether governments have done sufficient damage to local communities and indigenous peoples in the name of Paris, you know, this is something that must be rejected. It is disgraceful for governments toeven put such steps on the table.

What we call on parties here is to reject any text on Article 6 is that would fail to meet the most basic human rights. The most appalling thing in this text that we need to provision for this absence of human rights to be revised in 2028.

@duycks In Paris governments comited to respect human rights in climate action that they are implementing here. In the article 6 text that we have seen this morning, there is no section that would protect local communities against human rights abuses in the name of climate action

#COP25 is heading towards a downward spiral with dilution of language on ambition, on human rights, on carbon markets on finance for loss and damage. 
As people demand more, governments are screwing up with impunity.
Where are the climate leaders?

We don't think that this text can be a basis for a decent outcome here, and this message is particularly to the EU. There is a long standing position from the EU not to accept any carry over, units to the new regime. We call on them, especially VP Timmermans to reject this.

Instead of coming here and improving our targets, what countries would end up doing is even slice out the little ambition that there is. So what we're what we're now calling for countries, is to reject the text as it is and continue negotiations as a whole.
@ulriikkaaarnio: The Article 6 text is unaccepted, there is no option for not carrying over Kyoto units to the new regime, and this would undermine the little ambition that we have in the industry.

We don't see any progress on finance coming in. We can't just keep calling for ambition from developing countries without putting money on the table. This place is for global justice, not for workshops and reports, we have to act so that we can respond to the climate emergency.

The United States, joined by European Union, Australia and Canada are responsible for this bullying. It seems we are going to leave this COP with no support for people, leaving them on their own. Ambition cannot happen without finance.

@harjeet11: USA is holding the progress on loss and damage finance hostage just because it is interested in only covering its own administration and polluting industries. Whatever little progress we made is also stuck because of the bullying and blocking that has happened.

The planet is on fire and our window of escape is getting harder and harder to reach the longer we fail to act. Ministers here must strengthen the final decision to respond to the mounting impacts devastating communities and ecosystems, all over the world, failure is unacceptable

#UNGA

We call on countries to honour their commitment to the #ParisAgreement & to ensure that updated NDCs are a product of collaborative processes, raise ambition significantly & are in line with principles of equity & fairshares to keep warming below #1o5C
https://t.co/HWC6KYGs6X

The @UNFCCC needs to ensure that the ratchet mechanism, an essential part of the Paris Agreement, is functional. Brazil's NDC should not be accepted under the #ParisAgreement, much less welcomed. This sets a worrying precedent and can weaken the #ParisAgreement

Citing the need for $10 billion a year to meet its climate targets when the previous intended NDC stated that Brazil‚Äôs climate goals were not contingent on international support shows the complete lack of clarity in Brazil‚Äôs new NDC. 
Read the letter https://t.co/HWC6KYGs6X

üáßüá∑ NDC lacks consultation, transparency & participation from civil society, academia & scientists. The NDC says "institutional interactions between government & civil society take place through the Brazilian Forum on Climate change". There was no interaction in this process.

The üáßüá∑ NDC submitted on 9 December 2020 fails to increase ambition and is in fact a regression from the previous NDC. As the sixth largest global GHG emitter, and a key economy in Latin America, Brazil has a critical role to stop the climate crisis.

Specific clauses in the #ParisAgreement explain the progression principle on climate ambition, and any regression or backsliding in the ambition of updated or successive NDCs is a violation of the #ParisAgreement and will delay urgent climate action.

As countries continue to share their updated nationally determined contributions (NDC), it is important to call out those submitting weak & regressive NDCs that slide back on ambition and threaten the integrity of the #ParisAgreement & delay action on the climate crisis.

Led by Brazilian civil society groups, @CANIntl has issued a  letter to @UNFCCC about worrying red flags in Brazil's nationally determined contribution (NDC) submitted in December 9, 2020 that threatens to undermine the integrity of the #ParisAgreement --> https://t.co/HWC6KYGs6X https://t.co/JNf8lswXGD

"The latest data on EU emissions show that the bloc is following the right path, but now it needs to hit the ground running as science is clear that action in the short term is key to limiting catastrophic climate change impacts."

"Let the 5th anniversary of the #ParisAgreement serve as a reminder to them of what needs to be done. We have one planet, five years, and countless lives - we need to make this anniversary count." -@LiShuo_GP Senior Global Policy Advisor, @GreenpeaceEAsia

.#COP26 must open a political space for discussions on climate induced #LossAndDamage & commit to a funding mechanism to tackle impacts. 
The needs of vulnerable communities least equipped to cope with impacts they did nothing to cause is an urgency that cannot be ignored. 12/n

The @g20org leaders meeting before COP must be an opportunity to secure more finance from rich countries. Major emitters who have not submitted enhanced NDCs must do so before they arrive in Glasgow - all eyes on: Australia, Brazil, India, China, Mexico, Japan & S Korea. 11/n

Lack of finance can make it very challenging to find any common ground for a global response to the #climatecrisis. This is the moment we need a concerted global effort & serious implementation of the #ParisAgreement in all countries. 
This decade is decisive! 10/n

Ahead of #COP26, we need renewed trust in the multilateral process. This starts with keeping promises. There is still a shortfall in  $100bn target & this was money due in 2020! 
We are nearing the end of 2021. A finance deficit translates into a trust deficit. 9/n

China's plan to stop building coal plants abroad is a death knell for coal. It should also be for  fossil fuels like oil & gas. ALL fossil fuel expansion must stop & subsidies must be phased out from this year, if we are to keep the #1o5C goal alive. 8/n

https://t.co/diE7Oql2Ho

In this context, finance from rich countries is critical and must be stepped up urgently to meet this moment of transition. 
Developing countries cannot make the Just Transition on their own, given their existing energy scarcity & development deficit. üí∞üí∞üí∞ is critical! 7/n

We need to see how this will be implemented. To forgo their dependence on coal, poor & emerging economies need to massively ramp up on clean energy: on new infrastructure, finance, technology & know-how to ensure a seamless and Just Transition to #RenewableEnergy systems. 6/n

China's announcement to stop building coal plants abroad is a welcome and an important sign that coal is history. China must also take appropriate steps at home & stop expanding its domestic coal fleet. 5/n

Relative to its wealth and emissions, the US' fair share is closer to about $40bn-$50bn a year. Some estimates show the US owes about $800bn by 2030 to meet its responsibility towards fixing the #climatecrisis. 4/n

Read ---> https://t.co/nIetPmqpDC

In terms of US' fair share on climate finance as a whole, it still falls seriously short. To protect climate vulnerable countries & communities, the scale of  finance must be in the 100s of billions. 

The $100bn/ year is the bare minimum, the absolute floor of current needs.3/n

The US pledge to double climate finance is welcome, any increase in climate finance at this point is critical & helps bridge the gap in $100bn promised in 2020. 

A recent Oxfam report shows this gap which  severely undermines trust before #COP26. 2/n

https://t.co/FNDDMxRVQL

RT @WGC_Climate: üì¢Our close ally network @CANIntl
is calling for a postponement of COP26. We all agree that urgent climate action is still‚Ä¶

Escalating climate impacts all over the world and the most recent IPCC report are a reminder that consistent, urgent and transformative action on the ground to avert the worst of the climate crisis is needed everyday, day after day.

Full statement : https://t.co/SgIUs8H2ci

We will continue our work to push political leaders to deliver ambitious national climate targets, fulfil their responsibilities on climate finance, phase out fossil fuels and address the needs of the most vulnerable people experiencing loss and damage.
As accredited observers to the @UNFCCC negotiations, CAN has been a key player in every COP since it started in 1995, advocating for the strongest response from governments to the climate emergency.
CAN acknowledges the difficulties in holding a COP during a pandemic. This call to postpone COP26 does not in any way imply a postponement of urgent climate action or a boycott of the climate talks.

RT @CANEurope: ‚û°Ô∏èVaccine inequity
‚û°Ô∏èunaffordable accommodation
‚û°Ô∏ètravel challenges 
‚û°Ô∏èand new surges in the Covid19 pandemic 
...will lock‚Ä¶

While  @COP26  Presidency promised to fast-track vaccines to delegates in need of them, those who applied for this are yet to receive their first jabs as of today. We note that the COP Presidency has now announced that delegates will be vaccinated this week, though it's too late.
The full and meaningful representation of those on the frontlines of the climate emergency and with the least resources to cope is critical to produce a credible political outcome from #COP26.

This exclusion poses serious & long-lasting implications for issues that will be under deliberation at this COP  that are extremely important to developing countries, including on climate finance, loss and damage and carbon market rules, among others.

An in-person COP in early November would de facto exclude many government delegates, civil society campaigners and journalists, particularly from Global South countries, many of which are on the UK‚Äôs Covid19 ‚Äòred list‚Äô.

With  two months to go, it is evident that a safe, inclusive & just global climate conference is impossible given the failure to support access to vaccines to millions of people in poor countries, rising costs of travel and accommodation, &  the uncertainty with the pandemic.
